image.altText: Close up of woman with brown hair tied back has gold framed glasses, with pale skin and brown eyes. She looks ahead solemnly.

props.synopsis: Tayla-Jane Jackson had a late-term abortion in 2023 with the agreement of two doctors. She does not want a private member's bill introduced by Liberal MLC Ben Hood to pass parliament.

title.children: Tayla-Jane needed a late-term abortion. Here's why she doesn't agree with proposed changes to SA's abortion laws

image.altText: A waterway closed over by sand.

props.synopsis: A freak storm brought nearly 100,000 cubic metres of sand into the entrance of Cape Jaffa's marina, but the South Australian government says it can't help the local council.

title.children: Popular marina closed off by enough sand to fill nearly 40 Olympic pools

image.altText: A rocket flies over farmland

props.synopsis: A Canadian company has signed a deal to test its rocket in South Australia next year. If successful, it will be the first time a rocket reaches space from the remote Koonibba base.

title.children: Tiny South Australian town to host first rocket launch to space

image.altText: A politician speaking to the media.

props.synopsis: David Speirs, who held the role of SA opposition leader for almost two-and-a-half years, formally quits parliament 10 days after he revealed police had arrested him on suspicion of drug offences.

title.children: Former Liberal leader officially quits SA parliament days after police said he was facing drug charges

image.altText: A man wearing a green jacket and hat holding tomatoes.

props.synopsis: Tomato growers placed into quarantine after the discovery of the tomato brown rugose virus say authorities should have been better prepared for the arrival of the virus.

title.children: 'Devastated': Tens of millions of dollars in losses smash Australian tomato farmers

image.altText: a grandmother, daughter and grandaughter on a horse in an equestrian competition.

props.synopsis: Country shows are about more than rides and show bags. Many say they are a lifeline for farmers and regional communities doing it tough.

title.children: What agricultural shows mean to farming communities during tough seasons

image.altText: Hainsworth

props.synopsis: A five-hour police interview with accused serial killer Steven Hainsworth reveals his DNA was found at the scene of his aunt's murder and that he pawned some of her belongings within hours of her death.

title.children: Police grill alleged triple murderer in recorded interview

image.altText: Riverlea

props.synopsis: Part of the Riverlea development was brought to a halt after Indigenous remains were found at the $3 billion housing estate last year. Now the SA government has given developers the go ahead, with conditions, in what one senior Kaurna woman has described as "bittersweet".

title.children: Aboriginal remains were found at this housing development. Now, construction can resume

image.altText: Selfie of a man wearing a cap and safety gear inside a helicopter

props.synopsis: Being given just six months to live came as a shock to Craig Pankhurst because he assumed not hearing from the doctor about his most recent prostate-specific antigen test was a good thing. But it wasn't.

title.children: It shouldn't have taken a 'crook tooth' for Craig to learn he had life-threatening prostate cancer

image.altText: A close up of Donald Trump dancing at campaign event

props.synopsis: The US presidential candidate wrapped up his event ahead of schedule but remained on stage while nine songs played.

title.children: Donald Trump turns campaign event into impromptu musical session

image.altText: ACT Labor Leader Andrew Barr stands on a stage speaking behind a podium.

props.synopsis: The ACT chief minister says it was a mistake to appoint Walter Sofronoff to head an inquiry into the trial of Bruce Lehrmann.

title.children: Barr says Sofronoff's appointment to board of inquiry a 'mistake'

image.altText: Troy Bell walks outside a court building holding a note pad.

props.synopsis: Independent Mount Gambier MP Troy Bell says he will fight the jury's guilty verdicts and hopes to clear his name while continuing to represent his community.

title.children: MP found guilty of fraud offences vows to clear his name

image.altText: An older couple smile, standing in a kitchen holding kitchen utensils over a pot full of food.

props.synopsis: The latest Foodbank Hunger Report has found 3.4 million households across Australia are experiencing food insecurity, with low income earners having to skip meals or eat less because they cannot afford enough food.

title.children: These pensioners feed vulnerable families. They're seeing a disturbing trend that's been echoed in a new hunger report

image.altText: Bailey Smith screams

props.synopsis: A flurry of big-name players officially join new teams in the final minutes of the AFL trade period. Follow live.

title.children: Smith dealt to Cats, Stringer joins Giants as trade deadline day springs to life in final minutes

image.altText: A family photo with four people - Danniel, his two children and his wife Caitland on a white bed smiling.

props.synopsis: A Brisbane inquiry has heard that four defence members killed in a defence helicopter crash were experiencing "hazardous" fatigue levels.

title.children: Brisbane inquiry into fatal army helicopter crash reveals men were flying at 'hazardous' fatigue levels

image.altText: A group of people holding signs and flags walk in a protest rally.

props.synopsis: Staff at the Australian National University in Canberra have been asked to forgo an agreed pay rise amid efforts to get the university's budget under control.

title.children: 'I know this is a big ask': ANU staff urged to forgo agreed pay rise to keep university afloat

image.altText: a woman giving the finger at a man as he walks away

props.synopsis: Elizabeth Lee made the gesture towards a journalist at a press conference after the ACT Property Council's leaders' debate on Wednesday.

title.children: Canberra Liberals leader Elizabeth Lee makes rude gesture at journalist following tense press conference exchange

image.altText: A cloud of grey dusty smoke rises in the middle of a tightly packed city of apartments

props.synopsis: A barrage of Israeli air strikes hit towns across southern Lebanon and Beirut's southern suburbs. Meanwhile, the Israeli prime minister dismisses calls for a ceasefire.

title.children: Mayor of Lebanese town killed in Israeli strikes as Netanyahu rejects calls for ceasefire

image.altText: A composite image of Leanne Pompeani, with the iamge on the left showing an Asics logo and the logo removed on the right.

props.synopsis: The Melbourne Marathon Festival has apologised after an image of a winning athlete posted to its Instagram page was apparently edited to obscure the logo of a competitor of its naming-rights sponsor.

title.children: Nike-sponsored Melbourne Marathon apologises after sharing photo of winner with Asics logo edited out

image.altText: Five beers are held up as people cheers

props.synopsis: Prague has banned night-time pub crawls organised by travel agencies. Is this the end of the stag do?

title.children: World's thirstiest nation bans organised night-time pub crawls

image.altText: a man stands in a gallery smiling at the camera with art in the background

props.synopsis: Iain Dawson has pleaded guilty to transferring $34,000 of art gallery funds into his own bank account.

title.children: Former art gallery director guilty of theft of $34,000 of Archibald ticket sales

image.altText: An older woman with short grey hair and rounded glasses smiles.

props.synopsis: The federal government's threat to ban excessive debit card surcharges by 2026 has been welcomed by customers and small businesses who have been hit with higher costs for years — but not everyone is on board.

title.children: 'I was quite shocked': Convenience almost cost one woman $150 in card surcharges

image.altText: A streak of white among a purple sky above green grass at night

props.synopsis: The phenomenon is not well understood, and an astrophysicist says it is hard to predict when and where Steve will appear next.

title.children: Photographers looking for Aurora Australis capture mysterious phenomenon Steve instead

image.altText: A close up photo of a man wearing a suit and blue tie.

props.synopsis: The US government warns Israel that if it does not improve access to humanitarian aid in Gaza in the next 30 days, American military funding to the country may be cut.

title.children: White House's $26.7b warning to Israel: Improve aid or we'll cut your military funding

image.altText: Two young men smile for the camera on the red carpet for the 2019 Logies.

props.synopsis: Radio host, TV star and podcaster Hamish Blake on his secret fitness training, taking up golf, the "barbs that stick in your heart" when raising children, and other parenting challenges.

title.children: 'A fight that's ultimately futile': Hamish Blake on facing his own mortality in his home gym

image.altText: Reko Rennie wearing black stands in front of a neon red sign saying REMEMBER ME on a black wall

props.synopsis: The Kamilaroi artist started out spraying graffiti around Melbourne's west in the 80s. Today, he's the subject of a major survey exhibition at NGV Australia.

title.children: How Reko Rennie went from tagging train carriages in Melbourne's west to studying art in Paris

image.altText: man with tower in bakground

props.synopsis: Around 60,000 devices including mobile phones, medical devices and alarms will not work beyond October 28 when Optus and Telstra shut down their 3G networks and the government is urging people to be prepared.

title.children: Two weeks from Australia's 3G shutdown, tens of thousands of devices still need updating

image.altText: A sign that says 24/7 banking with a Westpac logo next to it.

props.synopsis: Customers with Westpac and St George have experienced difficulties accessing their internet banking for the third day in a row. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the government has been in contact with the bank.

title.children: 'Really concerning': Treasurer responds to Westpac outages

image.altText: Young man smiling with hands in the air, being held up by a man with people surrounding him smiling

props.synopsis: Nima Rinji Sherpa has returned home to Nepal, after climbing 14 of the world's peaks above 8,000 metres and is calling on the younger generation of Sherpas to rise above the stereotype of being support climbers and embrace their potential as top-tier athletes.

title.children: 'We are not just guides, we are trailblazers': Nepali teen becomes the youngest person to climb world's highest peaks

image.altText: Aerial view of beach, on sunny day with homes and escarpment in the background

props.synopsis: A judge has ruled a man convicted of murdering a child when he was a teenager "freely and voluntarily" interacted with a woman and her toddler at the beach.

title.children: Murderer breached supervision order by approaching woman and child at NSW beach

image.altText: Medibank Private

props.synopsis: New government figures show the number of people with top-level gold health insurance coverage has dropped by more than 400,000 between December 2020 and the end of last year.

title.children: Warnings issued to those downgrading health insurance

image.altText: A gloved hand holds a black spherical piece of debris.

props.synopsis: Mysterious black spheres washed up on Coogee Beach on Tuesday. The beach has been closed until further notice as Randwick City Council works to safely remove the debris and investigates.

title.children: Sydney's Coogee Beach shut after discovery of mysterious black balls

image.altText: A man in a suit stands in front of a woman in a pink jacket, two men in suits and a man in a cammo Navy outfit in front of a

props.synopsis: The Henderson shipyard will house a multi-billion-dollar defence precinct for naval shipbuilding and servicing of AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines, creating an industry the state government claims will rival WA's massive resources sector.

title.children: Thousands of jobs set to be created at new Perth defence shipbuilding and submarine maintenance precinct

image.altText: Ollie Olsen in a 1991 promo shot for his project Third Eye.

props.synopsis: Ian 'Ollie' Olsen, a significant figure in Australia's post-punk scene and a pioneer in experimental electronic music, has died following a lengthy illness.

title.children: Ollie Olsen, celebrated musician and Michael Hutchence collaborator, dies age 66
